Elizabeth is excited to be taking out her first loan with ID-Ghana through Kiva. She sells vegetables including tomatos, onions, garden eggs and also cassava and rice etc. She has been in this business for four years. She plans to use the loan amount of GHS 400 to buy vegetables, rice and cassava to sell to customers. She will save part of the profit and use the remainder to provide for her children and home. 

In the near future, Elizabeth wants to build her own house. She dreams of becoming a professional and having a successful business. 

The group needs a total amount of GHS 3,800 to support their businesses which include buying and selling wigs, second hand clothing, selling bed sheets, tomato, cassava, flour, soap and soft drinks.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, rice and cassava to sell to customers.

loans.name: Sunantra

texts.en:
Sunantra just began working with Ruma from 26 July 2013 to run Ruma’s new business – serving cash in and cash out customers’ money to Ruma’s bank partner. As a new agent in Ruma, Sunantra hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital in order to start his new business. Sunantra wishes this new business to be another source of his income.

Sunantra lives in Banjar Pengragoan Pangin Tukad, Bali, an rural area about four hours from Denpasar. Sunantra is married and has two children (a girl and a boy).

Prior to joining Ruma, Sunantra worked as a farmer.

loans.use: to have start up credits to process branchless banking products within the pilot period.

loans.name: Niyazi

texts.en:
Niyazi is 48 years old .He is married and he has a one son. Niyazi  is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with  his family  in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. He is a farmer and has raised seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last 14 years. During these years  Niyazi  gained enough skills and experience to run the business. He chose this crop business because it is profitable and fresh fruits and vegetables are in high demand. People use fresh vegetables every day and consider them healthy. Many national dishes are made of vegetables, like pilau and dolma. Fresh fruits are served at every table in an Azerbaijan family and also are used in fresh punch. Niyazi usually sells his crop in the central bazaar. His monthly income is 100 AZN.

As these products are in high demand,  Niyazi  wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to cover market demand. For this purpose, he applied for 2000 AZN. He will buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers. This will be his fourth  loan and he has a good client history.

loans.use: to buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married with two school-going children .She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees.

She sells fruit in her stall such as oranges, mangoes, and avocados.

She is requesting Ksh.10,000 to purchase two sacks of fruit such as oranges, mangoes and avocados for resale. She joined Yehu for financial support.

loans.use: to purchase two sacks of fruit such as oranges, mangoes and avocados for resale.

loans.name: Shiella

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Shiella works hard to support her family.

She has a 'buy and sell' vegetable business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Shiella is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase more vegetables to sell in her vegetable stall.

Shiella has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables to sell in her vegetable stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies for her coffee crop.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is married and has children who attend school. She owns a house that has no electricity and piped water.

She sells fruits and green vegetables and she always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more and save money in order to have a more formal establishment. She is requesting a loan to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.use: to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Baylar

texts.en:
Baylar is an IDP (internally displaced person) from Fizuli city. Now he lives in the Fizuli region. Baylar is 22 years old, and he is engaged. He started his business six months ago. He is a fitter (a person who uses machine tools to make or modify parts). 

Now he needs a loan of 1,250 AZN to buy an apparatus for his business. In the future, Baylar wants to have a big place for working and to have an employee. This will be more profitable for his business. Baylar want to get married and have three children. He is thankful to Komak and Kiva for helping him.

loans.use: to buy an apparatus for his business

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La  señora María  de 41 años de edad es soltera tiene tres hijos que dependen de ella vive  en la comunidad de San Lorenzo, en la zona sur de Honduras.

Doña María se dedica desde 13 años a negocio de corte de pelo y  también tiene negocio de venta de joyería,  se transporta en su vehículo a los diferentes lugares donde distribuye este tipo de joyas.
Doña María se caracteriza por su amabilidad y buen trato a las personas, está luchando por salir adelante y darles una buena educación a sus hijos.
Doña María está solicitando el préstamo para surtir de productos de belleza y joyería ya que se aproxima la feria de San Lorenzo y desea estar preparada para atender mejor a su clientela  con el apoyo del préstamo ella pretende mejorar su negocio y obtener más ganancias. 
Doña María su sueño es crecer más en su negocio.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2013.
texts.en:
María, 41, is single and has three children that depend on her; she lives in the community of San Lorenzo in the southern zone of Honduras.  For the last 13 years, María has worked cutting hair and she also has a business selling jewelry.  She transports herself in her vehicle to the various places where she sells this type of jewelry.

María is noted for her kindness and the good way she treats people.  She’s striving to get ahead and to provide a good education for her children.

María is requesting the loan to stock up on beauty supplies and jewelry because the feast of Saint Lorenzo is approaching and she wants to be prepared to better provide for her customers.  With support from the loan she intends to improve the business and earn higher profits.  María’s dream is to grow more in her business.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - July, 2013.

loans.use: to buy a hair dryer, scissors, scalp treatment drops and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy items like beer, washing powder, soaps, salt and other items

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is  married and has  children  who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a fish selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors. In addition she also operates a fruit-selling business, another source of income. 

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase fish and cooking oil for the preparation of fried fish. She decided to join to acquire financial services for her business growth.

loans.use: to purchase fish and cooking oil for the preparation of fried fish.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is married with two children and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of tailoring and has been in this business for 7 years. 

She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more rolls of clothing materials and threads. She works from home six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only. She generates additional income through selling Cattens. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. 

She aspires to own 5 sewing machines and also to employ people to assist in tailoring. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more rolls of clothing materials and threads.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy mulch

loans.name: Kilesi

texts.en:
Kilesi is 49 years old, from Naivasha, and he is married and blessed with five children, all of whom are in school.

Kilesi is a farmer and he has been in the business for the past many years. He has applied for his first loan from Kenya Agency for Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) to enable him to buy fertilizer and seedlings for use on his farm.

He hopes to become the leading farmer in his area.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings to use on his farm.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 42-year-old married woman. She has two children ages 9 years and 16 years. She describes herself to be committed and motivated.

Alice operates an M-pesa, where she offers mobile-phone-based money-transfer services. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located in a strategic place and her customers are of all types.

She will use the loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to add financial float (electronic credits to sell in her mobile money business). Her business goal is to expand the premise within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Alice's previous loan of KES 20,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to purchase financial float.

loans.name: Mable

texts.fr: Afin d'acheter des produits cosmétiques et des boissons, madame Mablé sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour atteindre son objectif. Elle est veuve avec 04 enfants en charge. Madame Mablé espère à l'avenir créer d'autres boutiques et assurer les besoins primaires de la famille. Elle est âgée de 54ans avec une ancienneté de 19ans dans l'activité.
texts.en:
In order to buy cosmetic products and drinks, Madame  Mable is asking WAGES for a first loan to attain her goal. She is a widow with four children in her care. 

Madame Mable hopes in future to create other shops and ensure the basic needs of her family. She is 54 years old with 19 years' experience in her business.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products and drinks.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a forty-year-old woman, married to Daniel, and a mother of two lovely children. She runs a beauty salon in Kangemi and also sells beauty products. Alice has been in this business for one year now. She gets a monthly income of twenty thousand shillings.

This will be Alice's first loan with KADET LTD. She plans to use the money to buy cosmetics, hair weaves, etc. so as to stock and expand her business.

In the future, Alice desires to own a wholesale beauty shop.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, hair weaves, etc.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has been blessed with children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. She cites paying for food and school fees as her major challenge.

She has operated a fruit selling business, which she sells to her neighbors and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of bulkiness of goods hence high cost of transportation. 

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fruit to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Aku

texts.fr: Femme d'un déclarant en douane, madame Aku âgée de 44ans est mère de 03 enfants tous scolarisés. Elle a démarré son activité en 2009 et revend des produits d'alimentation générale. Son stock s'épuise de jour en jour et n’arrivant plus à satisfaire les demandes des clients, elle fait son second crédit à WAGES pour s'approvisionner en marchandises afin de ne pas perdre ses clients. Elle voudrait à l'avenir, élargir sa gamme de produits et assurer les moindres besoins de la famille.
texts.en: Wife of a customs agent, Madame Aku, aged 44, is the mother of three children, all enrolled in school. She started her business in 2009 and sells general merchandise. Her stock is beginning to run low and she is no longer able to satisfy the demand of her clientele, so she has taken out her second loan from WAGES to stock up on merchandise lest she lose her clients. In future, she would like to expand the range of her products and be able to cover all the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy groceries for resale

loans.name: Rayitos De Luna Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “RAYITOS DE LUNA”  iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Olga es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: librería, artesanía en cuero (chicote), elaboración de queso, elaboración de pasankalla.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Olga es integrante, ella indica es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de lechería y venta de ganado; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió hace varios años atrás ya que su familia trabajaba en esta actividad, posteriormente a casarse decide emprender un negocio independiente donde trabaja con su familia.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de vacas lecheras) que adquirirá de las ferias aledañas y posteriormente a la crianza lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Rayitos de Luna” (Little Moonbeams) is starting its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Copacabana Community Center. This group consists of eight members and is led by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Olga as its president. The members of this Communal Bank engage in different businesses such as managing a bookstore, making handcrafted leather whips, making cheese, and making popcorn.

This loan will benefit small entrepreneurs such as Sra. Olga. She says that this is the first time she has joined Pro Mujer after receiving an invitation from a promoter of the organization who visited her at her house. Olga currently has a dairy business, but she also sells livestock. She gained knowledge of this trade by working in her family’s business for several years. After she got married, she started an independent business where she works with her own family.

The loan she is receiving now will be used to increase her capital for buying dairy cows that she will acquire at the neighboring fairs. Afterwards she will raise the animals before selling them from her business. Working in this manner enables her to generate income for maintaining her household. Olga is married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Olga said that she enjoys the training seminars about health and credit.

loans.use: to buy dairy cows.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en: Teresia is a 43-year-old married woman. She has three children with ages ranging from 12 years to 17 years. She describes herself as being motivated and hardworking. She operates a cereals and grocery store where she sells tomatoes, potatoes and other vegetables. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a strategic place. She describes her biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to her stock of tomatoes, onions and other vegetables. Her business goal is to be attractive to all clients within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan of KES 20,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to add to her stock of tomatoes, onions and other vegetables.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, blocks, sand, iron, and to pay for labor needed to build a wall.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is a 26-year-old, married woman. She has three children with ages ranging from two years to six years. She describes herself to be self-disciplined. 

Naomi operates a charcoal store where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a reliable place and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate stock. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add stocks of charcoal for resale. Her business goal is to grow within five years. She hopes that, in the future, she will be prosperous.

loans.use: add stocks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 52-year-old married man. He has 8 children. He describes himself to be enterprising and committed.

Samuel operates a hotel (restaurant) where he cooks food to sell. He has been involved in this business for 4 years. His primary customers are the general public.

He will use the loan of 15,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to add stock of maize, beans, cooking oil, and other items for preparing food in the hotel. His business goal is to open another branch within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will be self-reliant. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: add stock of maize, beans, cooking oil, and other items for preparing food in the hotel.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en: Teresia is a 36-year-old married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be enterprising. She owns a dairy farm with cows that produce milk, which she sells. She has been involved in this business for 15 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are hotels. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high costs of feed. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy one calf. Her business goal is to  increase the number of cows within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be able to build commercial houses. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy one calf

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pills, liquid medicines, gauze, first aid tape, cotton, and other items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy items like sugar, rice, soaps, sodas, cowpeas, and many others

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol is a single mother age 38 years. She has two daughters who are still attending primary schools.

Carol runs a retail shop in Kyotera town and she works seven days a week, each day for thirteen hours. She has been in this business since 1996 and she started to earn a living. This is her sixth loan cycle and now she now wants 2,000,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) to purchase more goods. She sells her goods to residents in Kyotera town and traders from the rural surroundings.

She hopes to increase her business to the level of wholesale. However, she faces the challenge of lack of enough capital for running her business. She describes herself as hard working woman. She requests that Ugafode and the Kiva lenders continue the good work.

loans.use: To buy retail items to sell.

loans.name: Milena

texts.es: Milena, de 33 años es una mujer trabajadora. Vive en compañía de su esposo y sus dos hijos; a los que cuida en su casa propia. Las actividades que desarrolla son diversas pues siempre se caracterizó por ser una mujer perseverante. La principal actividad económica que tiene es el tejido de diversas prendas de vestir a base de lana de alpaca procesada, comenta que en estos últimos meses empezó a usar lana reciclada, “es barata y tiene diversos colores y matizados”, afirma. Las prendas que teje son chalinas, gorras, ropones para recién nacidos además de chompas y sacos. Ya tiene muchos años de experiencia por lo que sus clientes más fieles le realizan pedidos constantes. Este es su tercer crédito con KIVA, donde se siente desarrollada, ya que obtiene la ayuda económica para progresar en su negocio. Milena, invertirá los S/.1500 soles en la compra de lana al por mayor para iniciar los pedidos que tiene.
texts.en:
Milena, age 33, is a hardworking woman. She lives with her husband and two children and cares for them in her own home. Her business activities are diverse since she has always been known as a persevering woman. Milena’s main business activity is knitting different types of clothes from processed alpaca wool. She says that in recent months she began using recycled wool. “It is cheaper and comes in different colors and hues,” says Milena. The types of clothes she knits include scarves, caps, infant gowns, sweaters, as well as bags. She has several years of experience and her customers have remained very loyal since they are constantly placing orders.

This is her third Kiva loan. Milena feels established since she is able to obtain the financial support needed to make progress in her business. She will invest 1,500 PEN in the purchase of wool in bulk so that she can begin her existing orders.

loans.use: to buy wool in bulk.

loans.name: Rosas Blancas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ROSAS BLANCAS”  iniciará el segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Tejada, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Elizabeth es la Secretaria. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de salchipapas, taller de llantería, venta de comida, venta de chicharrón de pollo, venta de tuntas y queso, venta de llantas, venta de muebles, venta de cosméticos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Elizabeth es integrante, ella indica que hace ocho meses que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación su madre que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tienda de llantas; este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años empezando con un poco capital y la orientación de su padre, en la actualidad está ampliando su capital.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de llantas) que adquirirá de las empresas distribuidoras de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener su economía ya que ella está estudiando.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le visitar los consultorios médicos.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Rosas Blancas” (White Roses), which is in its second loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of Centro Focal de Villa Tejada, comprises eight members, and Elizabeth is its board secretary. The members engage in various businesses: selling hot dogs and fries; operating a tire shop; preparing food; selling chicken chicharrón; preparing potato and cheese dumplings; selling tires; selling furniture; and selling cosmetics. 

This loan will help micro businesses such as Elizabeth's. She joined Pro Mujer eight months ago at the suggestion of her mother, who works with the institution. Elizabeth sells tires, a business she started a few years ago with a small amount of capital and guidance from her father, and she is now adding to her capital. She will use this loan to buy tires from distributors in the city of El Alto to sell in her shop. This work lets her earn enough to be financially stable, as she is still studying. When asked what she liked about Pro Mujer, she said access to medical appointments.

loans.use: to buy tires.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace, a 62 year old widowed mother of six from Thika, has a business as a mixed crop farmer. She earns a monthly income of KES 9,000, which she uses to support her family. This marks her sixth loan term with KADET after repaying her previous loans successfully.

With the loan she has applied from KADET LTD, she will be able to purchase fertilizers and seedlings. Additional income created will allow her improve the standard of living for her family. In the future, Grace would like to buy more goats. 

She hopes to save money to expand her farm land.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedlings.

loans.name: Artur

texts.en:
Artur lives with his family in the village of Zovaber in the Gegharkunik region. He is married and he has two sons. His wife is a teacher of mathematics at their local school. Artur’s retired father also lives with them; his mother has died recently.

Artur graduated from Yerevan State Polytechnic Institute. He has a specialty of engineer-machinist and he works at his specialty. Simultaneously, Artur, together with his father, is engaged in farming and agriculture. They mainly cultivate potato and cereal. They also breed a cow, 3 piglets, 8 sheep, 8 lambs, and 10 chickens. They manage to sell their farm products (potatoes, milk, cheese, meat, and eggs) from their house.

Artur plans to enlarge his cattle farm. He requests a loan of 600,000 Armenian drams (AMD). He also wants to buy some animal fodder.

loans.use: to enlarge his cattle farm and to buy some animal fodder.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 25-year-old married man. He has three children with ages ranging from 2 years to 6 years. He describes himself as being honest, responsible and goal oriented. He operates a green grocery where he sells bananas, oranges and other vegetables. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in an urban area and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be that some fruits are perishable. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to his stock of bananas, oranges and other fruits. His business goal is to own a wholesale business with all types of fruits within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will create employment. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to add to his stock of bananas, oranges and other fruits

loans.name: Primavera Group

texts.es:
El grupo Primavera está en su primer ciclo, ellas están aprendiendo a trabajar juntas, quieren ayudarse las unas a las otras  y de esa forma poder darle a su familia lo que necesitan.
Rumilda es parte de este grupo, se dedica a la venta de verduras, y con esto tiene los ingresos para poder ayudar a su familia y también ir invirtiendo en su negocio. Ella solicita de este crédito para poder comprar tomates, locotes, cebollas y demás insumos para poder seguir con sus ventas.
texts.en:
The group “Primavera” (Spring) is in its first loan cycle. They are learning to work together and help one another so that they can provide their families what they need.

Rumilda is part of this group. She sells vegetables and uses her earnings to help her family, but she also wants to invest in her business. Rumilda is requesting a loan in order to buy tomatoes, peppers, onions, and other produce so that she can continue making sales.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, peppers, onions, and other produce.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria viene de una familia humilde. Comenta que su familia tiene 3 fábricas de Ladrillos, por medio de la cual su familia le ha dado todo.
Ella está estudiando la carrera de enfermería con le esperanza de poder ayudar a las personas que necesiten atención en su salud. La Aspiración de Victoria es poder terminar su carrera y comenzar a trabajar como Licenciada en Enfermería  en la compañía de su ciudad y de esa manera ayudar a varias personas que necesitan en el sector de la salud y a la vez tener un ingreso mayor y más seguro para su hogar.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en sus gastos de manutención y de transporte, algo que le será muy útil para poder asistir a la universidad.
texts.en:
Victoria comes from a humble family. She says that her family owns three brick factories, which enabled her family to provide her with everything. Victoria is studying for a degree in Nursing and hopes to be able to help people in need of medical attention.

Her aspiration is to finish her degree and begin a job as a licensed nurse for a facility in the city. This would allow her to work in the healthcare field by helping many people. At the same time, she can earn a better income and feel more secure at home. Victoria is requesting a loan so that she can invest in her living and transportation expenses. This will be very useful while she is attending the university.

loans.use: to pay for living and transportation expenses while she is obtaining her nursing degree.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia de 56 años es una mujer trabajadora. Está casada con Felix y tiene 2 hijos con quienes vive en su casa propia. El trabajo al que se dedica Eugenia es variado. En las mañanas trabaja como personal de limpieza en la gobernación de su localidad, donde recibe un sueldo mensual, ya por las tardes se dedica al cuidado de sus sembríos de maíz, papa y habas; los cuales comercializa en el mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Huancayo, donde es muy conocida por la calidad de sus sembríos. Los fines de semana vende flores ornamentales en un lugar céntrico de la ciudad, cuenta que viaja una vez al mes a otra ciudad cercana a comprar flores diversas variedades, ya es conocida pues tiene 12 años dedicándose a esto. Pero como aprovecha todas las oportunidades que tiene, también cría animales como ovejas, cerdos y vacas, que después vende a mayor precio, cuando estén maduras. Este es su tercer crédito con KIVA, y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero que recibe para seguir adelante, además se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual.
Eugenia; invertirá los S/.3000 soles en la compra de abono orgánico para distribuir entre sus sembríos.
texts.en:
Eugenia, who is 56 years old, is a hard worker. She is married to Felix and has two children. She lives with them in the house they own. 

Eugenia works several jobs. In the morning she works as a janitor for the local administration, from whom she receives a monthly salary, and then in the afternoon she takes care of her crops. She grows corn, potatoes, and fava beans, which she sells at the wholesale market in the town of Huancayo, where she is very well known for the quality of her products. On the weekends she sells ornamental flowers downtown. She says she travels monthly to a nearby town to buy flowers of different kinds. She is well known because she has been doing this for over twelve years. But since she makes the most of every opportunity, she also raises animals like sheep, pigs, and cows, which she later sells at a higher price, when they are mature. 

This is her third Kiva loan, and she is grateful for the financial support she receives in order to keep going. She also promises to pay her installments on time. 

Eugenia will invest the 3,000 soles in the purchase of organic fertilizer to use on her crops.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Huayna Potosi Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “HUAYNA POTOSI”  iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Asunta es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: producción de verduras, venta de comida, constructor, venta de café, venta de comida, artesanía en tullmas, tejido de mantas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Asunta es integrante, ella indica es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió hace varios años atrás por iniciativa propia.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de papa) que adquirirá de las ferias aledañas y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene seis hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el crédito sin complicaciones.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Huayna Potosi,” which will begin its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of Centro Focal de Copacabana, comprises eight members, and Asunta is the president of its board. The members engage in a variety of businesses: growing vegetables; selling food; construction; selling coffee; crocheting caps; and weaving blankets. 

This loan will benefit micro businesses such as Asunta's. She said this is her first participation in Pro Mujer, which she joined after an associate of the institution visited her house. She learned her business, selling food, several years ago on her own. She will use this loan to buy potatoes at local fairs to use in the food she makes in her shop. 

This work lets her earn money to pay household expenses, as she is married and has six children. She said she likes that Pro Mujer provides funding without undue hassles.

loans.use: to buy potatoes.

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en:
Gagik is 39 years old and lives in Vanadzor with his family. He is married and has a son and a daughter, both of them school-aged.

For seven years now Gagik has worked as a tailor from a room in his house. He mainly makes gloves for construction workers and enjoys doing so. He either receives big orders or goes after sales of his products to local construction companies.

Gagik is applying for a 150,000 AMD loan through Nor Horizon to buy thread, fabric and other materials for his work. He also intends to start sewing footwear to sell at local markets. This loan will help him increase his family’s future income.

loans.use: to buy thread, fabric and other materials for his work.

loans.name: Hezbon

texts.en: Hezbon is a 39-year-old married man. He has 4 children with ages ranging from 6 to 12. He describes himself as business minded. He operates a barber shop. He has been involved in this business for 4 years. His business is located in a densely populated area. He describes his biggest business challenge as working for long hours. He will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy hair chemicals and other materials. His business goal is to open more barber shops within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will educate his children. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: buy hair chemicals and other materials.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en: Teresia is a 26-year-old married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from 2 years to 8 years. She describes herself to be business-minded. She operates a clothes store where she sells secondhand clothes. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a market area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be that her business is in an open-air market. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add stock of secondhand clothes for resale. Her business goal is to open a shop within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: add stock of secondhand clothes for resale

loans.name: Dodo

texts.en:
Dodo is 51 years old. She lives in the Terjola District in Georgia with her family: her husband, her grown son and her retired mother-in-law. The family runs an agricultural business. They own a dairy cow and sell cheese locally. Additionally, Dodo grows nuts and various of vegetables on the family-owned land and sells the harvest. Besides her agricultural activities, Dodo bakes cakes and distributes them to local groceries. Her son is a mini-bus driver who earns a monthly income. All the family members work hard all day long, but the existing income doesn't cover food and everyday expenses.

Dodo requested a loan from Credo, Kiva's field partner, to start up a family business and build a greenhouse. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages providing business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the vulnerable poor. These people do not have access to credit products, as they're regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income. With this loan, Dodo will purchase all the building materials for the greenhouse. After the greenhouse is built properly, Dodo will grow greens and various types of vegetables. The harvested products will be sold for a good price. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the family's income and improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: to construct a greenhouse.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose, 64, has five children ranging in age from ten to 28 years. She describes herself as honest, goal-oriented, responsible and a go-getter.

For the past ten years Rose has run a shop where she sells bread, milk, tea leaves, etc. Her shop is located in a marketplace, and her primary customers are middle to upper class customers. Inadequate stock is her biggest business challenge.

Rose is applying for a 40,000 KES loan through SMEP DTM to buy bread, sugar, milk, etc. This will be her second loan; the first of 20,000 KES was repaid successfully. Her goal is to own a wholesale business within five years. She hopes that in the future she will improve her living standards and create jobs for others.

loans.use: to buy bread, sugar, milk, etc. for her shop

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen, 25, is married and has one child who is two years old. He describes himself to be a disciplined person.

For the past two years Stephen has run a store where he offers electrical services and sells electrical supplies. His business is located in a busy area. Inadequate capital is his biggest business challenge.

Stephen is applying for a 20,000 KES loan through SMEP to buy electrical supplies such as cables and other items. His business goal is to be successful within five years. He hopes to become a prosperous man.

loans.use: to buy electrical supplies such as cables and other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anabel

texts.es:
La señora  Anabel de 41 años de edad,  casada y madre de dos hijas de edades entre 18 y 26 años se dedica  la venta de golosinas desde hace 6 años, en su negocio vende jugos naturales, tacos, enchilada, carne asada, tajaditas, sus clientes son todas las persona de su barrio quienes le visitan todas las tardes.
Doña Anabel está solicitando su segundo crédito y está muy contenta por el apoyo que esta recibiendo, actualmente quiere invertir en un nuevo negocio que es de  venta de zapatos y ropa.
Doña Anabel lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería como zapatos, blusas, camisas, faldas y pantalones ya que está comenzando este  nuevo negocio. Con el apoyo del préstamo espera surtir un poco su negocio y por ende mejorar sus ingresos.
Doña Anabel su sueño es que se le mejoren las ventas y tener muchos clientes. 

San Lorenzo, Honduras – Agosto del 2013
texts.en:
Sra. Anabel is 41 years old, married, and the mother of two daughters (ages 18 and 26). She has been selling snacks for six years. Anabel, in her business, sells natural juices, tacos, enchiladas, roasted meats, and fried plantains. Her customers include everyone in the neighborhood who visits her in the afternoons.

Doña Anabel is requesting her second loan and is very pleased with the support she has received. She now wants to invest in a new business of selling clothes and shoes. Anabel will invest in the purchase of merchandise such as shoes, blouses, shirts, skirts, and trousers. She has already started this new business, so the help of this loan will increase the inventory of her business a bit more and eventually lead to more income. Her dream is to improve her sales and acquire more customers.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – August 2013

loans.use: to buy shoes, blouses, shirts, skirts, and trousers for her second business.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is a 32-year-old married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from 2 years to 16 years. She describes herself as business minded. She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes for sale. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a market place that is busy. She describes her biggest business challenge to be working long hours. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to her stock of tailoring materials such as thread, sheets of cloth, etc. Her business goal is to open a large tailoring store within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to add to her stock of tailoring materials such as thread, sheets of cloth etc.

loans.name: Siempre Alegres Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “SIEMPRE ALEGRES  iniciará el cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Patacamaya, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Dominga es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de ganado, venta de ganado ovino, venta de comida, venta de ganado porcino, venta de comida.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Dominga es integrante, ella indica hace tres ciclos que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una Asesora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió hace varios años atrás porque ayudaba a su tía en la venta de este productos posteriormente con un pequeño capital emprendió su propio negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de carne) que adquirirá de las ferias aledañas y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Siempre Alegres” (Always Cheerful) is starting its fourth loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Patacamaya Community Center. This group consists of eight members and is led by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Dominga as its president. The members of this Communal Bank engage in different businesses such as selling livestock, selling sheep, selling food, selling pigs, and selling meals.

This loan will benefit small entrepreneurs such as Sra. Dominga. She says that she joined Pro Mujer three loan cycles ago after receiving an invitation from an adviser with the organization who visited her at home. Dominga currently has a business of selling food. She became knowledgeable about this trade after several years of helping her aunt sell these types of products. Afterwards, she used a small amount of her capital to start her own business.

The loan she is receiving now will be used to increase her capital for buying meat, which she will acquire at the neighboring fairs. She will then use the meat for preparing the meals that she sells from her vending stall. Working in this manner enables her to generate income for sustaining her household. Dominga is married and has three children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Dominga said that she enjoys the training seminars about health and credit.

loans.use: to buy meat.

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.es:
Visitación, de 40 años es una mujer trabajadora. Vive en compañía de su esposo Fortunato, con quien tiene 4 hijos, pero solo vive con 2 de ellos en su casa propia. 
Todas las mañanas desde las primeras horas del día emprende el viaje a un pueblito cercano a su hogar, donde se encuentran sus terrenos agrícolas alli siembra, papa y maíz en cantidad. Comenta que gracias a su esfuerzo y mucho trabajo logra obtener buenos ingresos los cuales invierte en la mejora constante de sus cultivos. “Hay temporadas muy bajas en donde el precio del maíz baja de manera considerable, en un inicio tenia pérdidas pero ahora hago secar el maíz y lo vendo dentro de unos meses como maíz seco que cuesta mucho más”, menciona. Es por esa razón que ahora solo tiene ganancias, además también se dedica a la crianza de animales menores, donde recibe un dinero extra.  Este es su segundo crédito con KIva, agradece el apoyo financiero recibido pues le permitirá mejorar sus ingresos, por ello promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Visitación, invertirá los S/.1500 soles en la compra de abono orgánico para nutrir sus sembríos.
texts.en:
Visitación is 40 and a hard worker. She lives with her husband, Fortunato, with whom she has four children, though just two of them live in her house. Early each morning, she travels to a nearby town where she grows potatoes and corn on her land. Thanks to much effort, she says she earns a good income, which she continuously reinvests in her plantings. 

“There are seasons when the price of corn is very low, and, at first, there were losses. Now I dry the corn and sell it a few months later at much better prices,” she says. Now she always shows a profit. She raises small farm animals for additional income.

This is her second loan cycle with Kiva, and she is grateful for the funding that lets her increase her income. She promises to make her payments on time. Visitación will use the loan of 1500 soles to buy organic fertilizer for her crops.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is a 42-year-old married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from 8 years to 20 years. She describes herself as honest. She operates a charcoal store where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for five years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be price changes. She will use the KES 25,000 loan to add to her stock of charcoal for resale. She hopes that in the future, she will be able to educate and feed her children.

loans.use: to add to her stock of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a 45-year-old married woman. She has five children with ages ranging from 7 to 22 years. She describes herself to be self-determined and confident. She operates a clothes store where she sells skirts, trousers, shirts, etc. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in an urban area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transport. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase skirts and trousers for resale. Her business goal is to own a boutique within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business and a united family. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: purchase skirts and trousers for resale

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en: Sharon is a 23-year-old married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be patient. She operates a retail store where she sells foodstuffs like sugar, flour, cooking oil, etc. She has been involved in this business for one year. Her primary customers are small-scale. She describes her biggest business challenge to be shortage of funds. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy stock of sugar, flour, and other items. Her business goal is to be a large-scale farmer of tea within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a better life. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM. She also sells milk to earn extra income.

loans.use: add stock of sugar, flour, and other items

loans.name: Turikumwe Cb Group

texts.en: Valencie is a group leader for the group called Turikumwe meaning "We are together" in English. The group is composed of different members. They sell different items but they have the same focus of upgrading their businesses. Valencie sells shoes and has been in the business for the past five years. With the loan, she would like to buy more shoes to sell. The profits from the business will be used to make more savings and provide food for the family. In the picture, Valencie holds up the bible.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene is a 31-year-old married woman. She has one child who is six years old. She describes herself to be faithful. She operates a beauty salon where she does hairdressing, etc. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a suburban area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough hair weaves and cosmetics. She will use the KES 30,000 loan to add stock of hair weaves and cosmetics. She hopes that in the future, she will be able to feed and educate her children comfortably. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan of KES 10,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: add stock of hair weaves and cosmetics

loans.name: Rodah

texts.en: Rodah is a 41-year-old married woman. She has six children with ages ranging from 8 years to 18 years. She describes herself as talkative. She operates a green grocery where she sells potatoes, tomatoes, etc. She has been involved in this business for 16 years. Her business is located in a rural area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough funds. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to her stock of tomatoes, potatoes and other vegetables. Her business goal is to open a shop within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan of KES 10,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to add to her stock of tomatoes, potatoes and other vegetables

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha is a 48-year-old married woman. She has three children. She describes herself as honest. She operates a beauty salon where she does hair treatment, hair weaving etc. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are females. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of funds. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy a hair dryer. Her business goal is to own at least two salons within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have businesses that can support her family. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a hair dryer

loans.name: Zaimwa

texts.en: Zaimwa is a married woman, and she has three children. She describes herself as ambitious. She operates a beauty salon, where she provides hair treatments, hair weaving, and other beauty-related services. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are ladies. She says her biggest business challenge is the lack of enough space in the salon. She will use the KES 30,000 loan to add to her stock of beauty items, for example, cosmetics and hair weaves. Her business goal is to own a big shop, within five years.

loans.use: to add to her stock of beauty items, for example, cosmetics and hair weaves

loans.name: Junnice

texts.en: Junnice is a single woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a charcoal store where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in an area with potential, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be government interferences. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to add to her stock of charcoal for resale. Her business goal is to grow within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will succeed. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a 33 year-old married woman. She has four children, with ages ranging from 2 years to 12 years. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a cereals store where she sells maize, beans, etc. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a viable place and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inflation of prices. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to add stock of maize and beans for resale. Her business goal is to own a wholesale store within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her standard of living. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM. She will use the anticipated profits to start a grinding mill.

loans.use: add stock of maize and beans for resale

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is an aging man of about 58 years, living in a rural setting. He has a family of five children that he takes care of. He does farming, and is also a seasonal produce trader, which earns him some additional income. He says he started the agricultural business to supplement his income from teaching.

Edward says that his major challenges are price fluctuations and long dry spells that reduce the farm's output. He hopes to use this loan to buy agricultural produce to sell at his store, especially sacks of beans and maize. This new inventory will help him improve his income sources and standard of living.

He says he has managed to construct a backyard at his home, making his quality of life improve. Edward hopes to retire from his government job, and have trading in produce be his source of income thereafter.

loans.use: to buy agricultural produce to sell at his store, especially sacks of beans and maize

loans.name: Victor Hernan

texts.es:
Victor es un hombre de 20 años, es soltero, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa con sus padres y hermanos, el es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo deseo de superación; gracias a su esfuerzo y al apoyo de sus padres, Victor se encuentra estudiando la carrera profesional de Derecho que desea.
por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Victor trabaja como empleado de limpieza en una empresa municipal de su ciudad, el trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 8 horas y cree que le va bien por su buen desempeño y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás.
Victor se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada comprará una moto lineal, la cual le servirá de mucho para transportarse desde las lejanías de su hogar hasta su centro de trabajo y universidad, de esta manera Victor podrá ahorrar un poco de dinero para invertirlo en sus estudios, ya que su gran sueño es convertirse en un buen profesional.
texts.en:
Victor is 20 years old. He is single and lives in the city of Pucallpa with his parents and siblings. Victor is a kind, hardworking, and enthusiastic person with a desire to overcome his situation. Thanks to his great effort and the support of his parents, Victor is currently studying Law like he has always wanted. By his own initiative and with much determination and dedication, Victor works as a janitor for a business in the city. He works 8-hour shifts every day and believes that things have gone well for him because of his quality performance and the kind way he treats others. 

Victor is very grateful to Kiva lenders. Thanks to the support offered to him through this loan, he will be able to buy a motorcycle, which will help him to travel the long way from home into the city where he works and studies. This way, Victor will be able to save some money to invest in his education. His biggest dream is to become a professional.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 30 years old. He is married and has three children between the ages of 5 and 1. His wife works as a farmer as well. With the loan, he wants to buy fertilizers and pay for labor costs during rice production. With the profits, he wants to upgrade his farming practices. Farming rice provides food for his family and helps them to sustain their standard of living. In the picture, his wife behind him is planting rice. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay for labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a 27 year old married woman. She has 3 children with ages ranging from 18 months to 6 years. She describes herself to be successful. She operates a clothes store where she sells second-hand clothes .She also owns a motorbike which she rents to customers for transport to earn an extra income. She has been involved in this business for 12 years. Her business is located in a strategic area along a busy industrial area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be that during the rain season, clothes in her store get dump. She will use the Kes 100,000 loan to add stock of clothes for resale and buy materials to modify the clothes stall. Her business goal is to invest in a motorcycle transport business with at least four motorbikes within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will put up a permanent clothes store and sell new clothes. She will use the anticipated profits to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: add stock of clothes for resale and buy materials to modify the clothes stall

loans.name: Benald

texts.en:
Benald is a married man.   He is thirty-one and has two children. Benald also takes care of three other children who are orphans. He is a businessman who deals in electronic appliances.  He works seven days a week.   Each day he works for fourteen hours in order to maximize the profits. He supplements his income with farming, where he grows coffee on a small scale. He has been in the electronics business since 2011 and he sells his goods to residents at the nearby fishing site.  He started this business in order to earn a living, and he has applied for this loan so that he can re-stock goods and be able serve his customers. His hopes are to expand his business, and he also hopes to buy a car for transporting his products to other remote fishing sites.

Benald faces challenges which include lack of enough capital and high transport costs. He describes himself as honest and hard-working. He requests Ugafode to continue giving services to those who need them.

loans.use: To buy stock for the electronics shop

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est constitué de quatre femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Sabalibougou dans le district de Bamako. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Sabalibougou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de condiments,  de vêtements, des chaussures en plastiques et du bois de chauffe. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1ercycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Kadiatou (femme assise en 2ème position de la droite vers la gauche) est une grande vendeuse de vêtements de toutes les qualités et de tous les âges. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 50 complets d’habits pour enfants dans le grand marché en gros. La revente se fait  au comptant et crédit à Sabalibougou et en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Kadiatou espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les besoins du foyer en produits de première nécessité. Madame Kadiatou a pour ambition d’acheter une parcelle à usage d’habitation pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
The Benkadi Group is made up of four married women living mainly in polygamous households. They have an average age of 39 years and an average of five children. They all live in the neighborhood of Sabalibougou in the district of Bamako. They know one another through ties of vicinity, kinship and their businesses in the Sabalibougou market. The members of the group are merchants with small businesses selling vegetable sauces, clothing, plastic shoes, and firewood. In order to increase their business capital, the group has decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso and are currently on their first group loan cycle.

Kadiatou (shown in the photo sitting second from the right) sells clothing of all qualities and all ages. She plans to use this loan to buy 50 full sets of clothing for children in the general wholesale market. She then resells her merchandise for cash and on credit in Sabalibougou and by traveling to her clientele, which is composed mainly of women.

With this loan, Kadiatou hopes to earn an average monthly revenue of 40,000 Francs CFA. She will use her income to reinvest in her business and to pay for household necessities. Kadiatou's aim is to purchase a plot of land for her children to live on.

loans.use: to purchase sets of children's clothing.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.en:
Delfina appreciates the previous loan she took from Kiva that enabled her make profits in her retail shop, thus improved her standard of living.

She is requesting a loan of KES 45,000 to purchase sacks of rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, soap, and tea leaves for her business.

She joined Yehu for financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, soap, and tea leaves for her business.

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean De Dieu is 33 years old. He is the father of three children between the ages of four and ten; they all go to school. He has been a rice farmer for the past ten years. He has requested the loan to buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during rice production. He plans to use the profits from the produce to renovate his house. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during rice production

loans.name: Eithel Antonio

texts.es:
Eithel es un hombre de 27 años, vive en la ciudad de Ica, en el distrito de Parcona con su esposa y sus dos pequeños hijos a quienes ama y son su principal razón en la vida, el es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que junto con su esposa dedican todos sus esfuerzos por sacar adelante a su familia; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tiene de trabajar, Eithel no ha podido estudiar la carrera profesional de Ingeniería de Sistemas que deseaba.
Por iniciativa propia, Eithel trabaja como operario de construcción en diversas obras de su ciudad, el trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por su buen desempeño y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás. 
Eithel se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada realizara la construcción de una habitación con materiales adecuados y resistentes para sus hijos, de esta manera Eithel brindará mayor seguridad y bienestar a su familia, así pues el seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de ver a sus hijos convertidos en buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
Eithel is 27 years old and lives in the Parcona district of the city of Ica with his wife and two young sons.  He loves his his wife and children and they are his main reason for living.  Eithel is very friendly, hard-working and enthusiastic and, alongside his wife, he puts all his efforts into helping the family get ahead.  Unfortunately, due to a lack of money and because he had to work, Eithel was not able to study computer programming as he had wanted.

Through his own initiative, Eithel works as a construction worker at various sites in the city.  He works every day for around ten hours and thinks it is going well because of the effort he puts in and because he treats others in a friendly way.

Eithel is very grateful to Kiva lenders as, thanks to the help provided, he will be able to build a room for his children with good and resistant materials.  Eithel will therefore provide better well-being and security to his family.  He will continue working and putting in the effort to achieve his big dream of seeing his children one day become professionals.

loans.use: to build a room.

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is 24 years old, single and lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He has completed secondary school only. 

He is characterized by working hard, so he is an employer currently. He lives in a rented house, and he intends to buy supplies for his house. 

He applied for a youth loan from AMB to buy furniture for his house. He hopes to have a savings amount so that he can buy a car and get married.

loans.use: to buy furniture for his house.

loans.name: Sol Naciente - 32 Group

texts.es: El Banco de emprendimiento SOL NACIENTE – 32  está compuesto por ocho integrantes, ocho mujeres y dos varones, la presidenta del banco es la Sra. Flora tiene 69 años, casada con hijos independientes,  ella se dedica a la venta de ropa,  sigue con esta actividad cuenta que le fue bastante bien con el crédito que lo utilizo en compra de ropa en  esta ocacion solicita el crédito para la compra de ropa como chamarras, algunos de los integrantes cambiaron, no tuvieron problemas en el pago de sus cuotas sino que ya no quisieron renovar su crédito, la Sra. Flora se siente agradecida por esta nueva oportunidad que le brindan ya que esto le permite mejorar en su negocio.
texts.en: The "Sol Naciente - 32" communal bank has nine members - eight women and one man.  The president is 69-year-old Flora.  She is married and has two children, who are now independent.  Flora makes a living selling clothes and is continuing with the business as it is going well following the loan that she used to buy clothes.  On this occasion she is applying for a loan to buy clothes such as overcoats.  Some of the group members have changed.  They did not have problems repaying their loans but they no longer wanted to renew them.  Flora is grateful for this now opportunity as it will allow her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes (overcoats) in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a variety of iron, links, rope, etc. for his business.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
Maria es una mujer de 39 años,vive en la ciudad de Ica, en el distrito de Parcona con su esposo y sus tres hijos, a quienes ama y son su principal razón en la vida, ella es una persona muy amable, trabajadora y entusiasta, que junto con su esposo dedican todos sus esfuerzos por sacar adelante a su familia;lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven, Maria no pudo estudiar la carrera profesional de Educación.
por iniciativa propia, Maria trabaja en su pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes y bebidas, ella trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por los buenos precios y por la dedicación de su trabajo.
Maria se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada comprará mayor cantidad y variedad de productos, de esta manera Maria tendrá su negocio mejor abastecido y atenderá a mas clientes, así pues ella seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de ver a sus hijos convertidos en buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
Maria is a 39-year-old woman. She lives in the city of Ica, in the Parcona district, with her husband and three children, whom she loves and are her principal reason for living. She is a very kind, hard-working, and enthusiastic person, who along with her husband dedicates all of her efforts to bringing her family out ahead. Unfortunately, because of a lack of economic resources and the necessity that she had of working from very young, Maria was not able to study for a career in education.

Through her own initiative, Maria works in her small business selling groceries and drinks. She works every day for approximately 10 hours and believes that it is going well for her because of her good prices and dedication to her job.

Maria is very thankful to the Kiva lenders, since thanks to the help provided, she will buy a larger quantity and variety of products. In this way, Maria will have her store better stocked and be able to attend to more customers. So, she will continue working and making an effort to achieve her greatest dream of seeing her children become good professionals.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Kenia Marisela

texts.es: Kenia, tiene 37 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene tres hijos  a su cargo y vive en el municipio de Quimistán, Santa Bárbara. Anteriormente trabajaba en Maquila, pero al quedar sin empleo decidió establecer su propio negocio de venta de comidas y golosinas en su casa. El negocio lo tiene hace más de un año y le ha ido bien. Ofrece desayunos, almuerzos, cenas, churros, refrescos, dulces, galletas etc. Ha solicitado el sexto ciclo de préstamos en ODEF el cual es por 15,000 lempiras. Ella va comprar insumos como carnes, bananos verdes, frijoles, harinas, manteca, refrescos, churros, etc. Para elaboración de comidas y golosinas para vender. Su meta es crecer en el negocio para poder ayudar a sus hijos.
texts.en: Kenia is 37 years old and a single mother to three children.  She lives in the town of Quimistán in Santa Bárbara.  Previously Kenia worked in Maquila but, when she came to be unemployed, she decided to start her own business selling meals and sweets out of her home.  She has had the business for more than a year and it has been going well.  Kenia offers breakfasts, lunches, dinners, churros, soft drinks, sweets, biscuits and more.  She is applying for a loan of 15,000 Lempira in the sixth loan cycle.  She will buy supplies such as meats, plantains, beans, flour, butter, soft drinks, churros and more, in order to prepare meals and sweets to sell.  Kenia's goal is to expand the business in order to be able to help her children.

loans.use: to buy supplies, such as meats, plantains, beans, flour, butter, soft drinks, churros and more, in order to prepare meals and sweets to sell.

loans.name: Yaneth

texts.es:
Yaneth tiene 19 años de edad y tiene una relación unión libre de la cual tiene una hija (Jaselina de 2 años de edad). Ella pertenece al banco comunal Santa Isabel de Jajahuana pues es una persona responsable y emprendedora entonces su actividad económica principal es la venta de productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, fideos, detergentes, pan, gaseosas, dulces, galletas y otros productos. Ella también se dedica al engorde de ganado y a la crianza de animales menores. En esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar mercadería como sacos de arroz y sacos de azúcar al por mayor pues los costos son más baratos. 

Yaneth nació en la comunidad de Jajahuana y vive en la misma comunidad donde nació. (La comunidad de Jajahuana está ubicado en el distrito de Challabamba dentro de la provincia de Paucartambo del departamento del Cusco, Perú).
texts.en:
Yaneth, 19, is in a common-law relationship and has a daughter (Jaselina, 2).  She belongs to Santa Isabel de Jajahuana Communal Bank.  She's a responsible and enterprising person.

Yaneth's main economic activity is selling staple products such as rice, sugar, pasta, detergent, bread, soda, sweets, cookies, and other products.  She also raises cattle and small animals.

She needs this loan to buy merchandise such as sacks of rice and sugar wholesale because the prices are lower.

Yaneth was born in the community of Jajahuana and lives in the same place.  (Jajahuana's located in the district of Challabamba between the departments of Paucartambo and Cusco, Peru.)

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice and sugar

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a 31-year-old, married man. He has one child, who is two years old. Jackson describes himself as humble. He operates a transport business, driving children to school. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in an urban area, and his primary customers are parents of school-going children. He says his biggest business challenge is that, during teachers' strikes and holidays, his income is low.

He will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy spare parts to service his vehicle. This is Jackson's second loan with SMEP-DTM. He repaid his previous loan successfully.

He will use the anticipated profits to buy a new vehicle. His business goal is to own a bus, within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be happy.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to service his vehicle

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  femmes du groupe Danaya sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages polygamiques avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Sabalibougou dans le district de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Sabalibougou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de poisson sec, d’huile de palme,  de fruits (patate), d’ustensiles plastic de cuisine et des habits de la friperie. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1ercycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Awa (femme assise au milieu sur la photo) est une grande commerçante d’ustensiles en plastique de toutes sortes à Sabalibougou. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter un colis d’ustensiles constitué de seaux, tasses, louches, assiettes et de bouilloires. Elle se ravitaille à Bamako et revend  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes à Sabalibougou et en ambulant. Madame Awa espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer l’entretien de ses enfants dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The Danaya Group is made up of five married women living mainly in polygamous households. They have an average age of 40 years and an average of six children. They all live in the neighborhood of Sabalibougou in the district of Bamako. They know one another through ties of vicinity and through their businesses in the Sabalibougou market. The members of the group are merchants with small businesses selling dried fish, palm oil, produce (potatoes), plastic kitchen utensils and used clothing. In order to increase their business capital, the group has decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso and are currently on their first group loan cycle.

Awa (shown seated in the center of the photo) sells plastic utensils of all types in Sabalibougou. She plans to use this loan to buy a parcel of items consisting of buckets, cups, ladles, plates and kettles. She purchases her merchandise in Bamako and resells it in Sabalibougou and by traveling to her clientele (composed mainly of women) for cash and on credit.

With this loan, Awa hopes to earn an average monthly revenue of 30,000 Francs CFA. She will use her income to reinvest in her business and to maintain her children while in this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to purchase plastic kitchen items.

loans.name: Anita

texts.es:
Anita tiene 24 años de edad, es una joven muy alegre y sobre todo tiene muchas ganas de salir adelante. Con mucho esfuerzo esta estudiando la de derecho, lo cual le permitió trabajar en una institución de su ciudad, con lo cual solventa los gastos de sus estudios, pero a pesar de ello siempre tuvo la idea de tener un negocio y tal es así que logro inicar su negocio de venta de ropa, con lo cual tiene un ingreso extra para los gastos del hogar.

Anita esta muy agradecida con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias al apoyo que le han brindado ella podrá comprar mercadería para su negocio como polos, short, entre otros; lo que le permitirá tener variedad de productos y seguir mejorando en su negocio, así ella seguirá luchando para poder hacer realidad su mas grande sueño:” Terminar su carrera”.
texts.en:
Anita is 24 years old. She is a very happy young woman who above all wants to come out ahead. With a lot of effort, she is studying law, which has allowed her to work in an institution in her city, with which she will pay all of her educational expenses. However, despite this, she always had the idea of having a store and that is how she managed to open her business selling clothing, with which she has an extra income for her home expenses.

Anita is very thankful to the Kiva lenders since thanks to the support that they have provided her, she will be able to buy merchandise for her business, such as t-shirts and shorts, among others, which will allow her to have a variety of products and continue improving her business. So, she will continue fighting to be able to make her greatest dream a reality: to finish her studies.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Nganzuva

texts.en:
Nganzuva is a married woman and has five, school-going children. She lives at her own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a kiosk shop, selling foods. Her potential customers are market dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuations of products in the market.

With the KES 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase more food to resell at her kiosk, including sacks of beans, cooking oil, wheat flour, and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more food to resell at her kiosk, including sacks of beans, cooking oil, and wheat flour

loans.name: José Luís

texts.es:
Don José tiene 48 años de edad, se dedica a la agricultura desde la edad de ocho años. Está acompañado con quien tiene tres hijos de 22, 19 y 15 años de edad;  todos viven con él y trabajan juntos. Solo se dedican al trabajo agrícola debido a que su nivel académico es únicamente primer grado solo sabe escribir su nombre.
